g.text: DNA methylation is an epigenetic mark that ensures silencing of transposable
elements (TEs) and affects gene expression in many organisms. The function of different DNA
methylation regulatory pathways has been largely characterized in the model plant
. However, far less is known about DNA methylation regulation and functions in basal
land plants. Here we focus on the liverwort
species that represents a basal lineage of land plants. We identified Mp
methylation at CG sites in angiosperms. We generated Mp
system, which showed a significant loss of CG methylation and severe morphological changes
and developmental defects. The mutants developed many adventitious shoot-like structures,
is required for maintaining differentiated cellular identities in the
gametophyte. Numerous TEs were up-regulated, even though non-CG methylation was highly
increased at TEs in the Mp
mutants. Closer inspection of CHG methylation revealed features
shows higher methylation level at CAG sites than at other CHG contexts and
CAG/CTG sites are mostly methylated asymmetrically
methylation reached comparable levels and symmetry upon loss of CG methylation. Our results
highlight the diversity of non-CG methylation regulatory mechanisms in plants.
